item.title: The complexities of the new EU Media Freedom Act
item.description:
Samira Asmaa Allioui, research and tutorial fellow at the Center for International and European Studies at the University of Strasbourg Photo credit: Bin im Garten, via Wikimedia Commons Journalists face various pressures. Recent years have seen media freedom, particularly media pluralism, under threat. On December 15, 2023, the European Council and Parliament reached an agreement on regulations to protect media freedom, pluralism, and editorial independence within the European Union. The EU Media Freedom Act (EMFA) aims for greater transparency in media ownership and safeguards against government surveillance and spyware targeting journalists...

item.title: Insights from interim proceedings: Amazon v DSA
item.description:
Laureline Lemoine, Senior Associate, AWO Agency Photo credit: KarleHorn, via Wikimedia Commons A recent legal challenge to the Digital Services Act (DSA) provides insight into how Amazon is approaching its obligations under the new law. The case, initiated by Amazon after being designated a Very Large Online Platform (VLOP), centers around two main arguments. First, Amazon contests the DSA requirement for an opt-out for recommender systems based on user profiling (Article 38), claiming it would negatively impact its business and users...

item.title: Unresolved concerns regarding the regulations for trusted flaggers under the Digital Services Act regime
item.description:
Alessandra Fratini and Giorgia Lo Tauro, FratiniVergano European Lawyers Photo credit: ** Lobo Studio Hamburg**, via Wikimedia Commons 1 Introduction The EU’s Digital Services Act (DSA) formally establishes the roles and responsibilities of “trusted flaggers,” important entities in the online world that have operated with varying degrees of influence since the early 2000s. This new framework aligns with the DSA’s goals: creating consistent, effective, and balanced rules across the EU to improve the online marketplace...
